dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: $20 billion in Tesla shares were sold by investors after its S&P 500 debut, which is just wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: twenty dollars billion in Tesla shares were sold by investors after its S&P five hundred debut, which is just wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Teslas Historic S&P 500 Debut Sparks Big Trading Volume As Investors Buy Over $80 Billion In Shares

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's not even the whole story—Tesla's also down 10% since early November, from $400 a share to around $360.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's not even the whole story-Tesla's also down ten percent since early November, from four hundred dollars a share to around three hundred sixty dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two months since the U.S. elected a more environmentally focused President in Joe Biden, the shift towards EVs has accelerated and can be seen in Teslas 76% share price rise since early November from $400 a share to $705.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just Tesla, right? Battery metal miners are getting hammered too. Pilbara Minerals, that Australian lithium producer, is down 17% in the same period.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not just Tesla, right? Battery metal miners are getting hammered too. Pilbara Minerals, that Australian lithium producer, is down seventeen percent in the same period.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pilbara Minerals, an Australian producer of lithium, is up 137% since early November.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oof, that's a double-your-money loss in just eight weeks for their shareholders. Really brutal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oof, that's a double-your-money loss in just eight weeks for their shareholders. Really brutal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While its easier for a relatively small company valued at $1.8 billion to rise faster than Tesla with its $670 billion stock market value, the double-your-money win in just eight weeks is very real for Pilbara shareholders.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's happening across the sector. Albemarle Corporation in the U.S. saw a 10% drop since November 4th.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's happening across the sector. Albemarle Corporation in the U.S. saw a ten percent drop since November fourth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S.-based Albemarle Corporation has enjoyed a 58% share price rise since November 4, up from $93.43 on the New York Stock Exchange to $147.52 at the close on Friday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Even graphite companies like Talga Group are down 15%. It feels like investors are just abandoning the whole battery metals story.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even graphite companies like Talga Group are down fifteen percent. It feels like investors are just abandoning the whole battery metals story.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Graphite explorers and producers have shared in the return of confidence in the battery metals story with Talga Group, an Australian-based and Swedish-focused developer of graphite products, up 65% since early November.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is kind of ironic because, like, this feels like a repeat of 2019, when mining stocks boomed and then totally busted because supply way outstripped EV demand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is kind of ironic because, like, this feels like a repeat of twenty nineteen, when mining stocks boomed and then totally busted because supply way outstripped E V demand.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For investors. whats happening with battery-metal miners looks like a re-run of the boom conditions in 2017 when share prices rocketed up despite sluggish EV sales.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And now with EV sales actually decreasing—Tesla itself had a 12% drop last year—it's like the party's over before it even got started again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And now with E V sales actually decreasing-Tesla itself had a twelve percent drop last year-it's like the party's over before it even got started again.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This time it should be different because EV demand really is rising as seen in last years 36% increase in Tesla sales despite the depressing effects of the Covid-19 pandemic on global mobility and overall vehicle demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Morgan Stanley just cut its lithium forecasts. They're predicting spodumene could fall from $395 a ton to just $290.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Morgan Stanley just cut its lithium forecasts. They're predicting spodumene could fall from three hundred ninety five dollars a ton to just two hundred ninety dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Goldman Sachs, late last month, lifted its forecasts for lithium. Spodumene (a primary ore of the metal) is tipped to rise from $395 a ton to $536/t this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and lithium hydroxide might drop to $7,000 a ton by 2023. That's a huge correction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and lithium hydroxide might drop to seven thousand dollars a ton by twenty twenty three. That's a huge correction.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lithium hydroxide (a processed form of the metal) is forecast to rise from $10,882/t to $11,800 and then up to $13,000/t in 2023.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So even though Mercedes-Benz is leading in EVs right now, the overall demand growth is slowing. Competition is rising, but so are obstacles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So even though Mercedes-Benz is leading in EVs right now, the overall demand growth is slowing. Competition is rising, but so are obstacles.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Tesla is the current EV leader, it is being joined in the race to overtake internal combustion engines by traditional vehicle leaders, such as Mercedes Benz, Toyota, Ford and Audi.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Government regulations aren't helping either—they're making drivers delay switching to electric.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Government regulations aren't helping either-they're making drivers delay switching to electric.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Increasing competition for EV sales, as obstacles such as limited charging stations and range anxiety are overcome, is being boosted by government incentives for drivers to make the switch.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So if surpluses pile up, these metal prices could really plummet further. Not a great outlook for miners.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So if surpluses pile up, these metal prices could really plummet further. Not a great outlook for miners.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If shortages do develop, battery metal prices could spike higher with a corresponding effect on share prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Nope. Feels like we're seeing history repeat itself, unfortunately.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope. Feels like we're seeing history repeat itself, unfortunately.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This time it should be different because EV demand really is rising as seen in last years 36% increase in Tesla sales despite the depressing effects of the Covid-19 pandemic on global mobility and overall vehicle demand.

artist_script:
$20 billion in Tesla shares were sold by investors after its S&P 500 debut, which is just wild.
HostB: Yeah, and that’s not even the whole story—Tesla’s also down 10% since early November, from $400 a share to around $360.
HostA: And it’s not just Tesla, right? Battery metal miners are getting hammered too. Pilbara Minerals, that Australian lithium producer, is down 17% in the same period.
HostB: Oof, that’s a double-your-money loss in just eight weeks for their shareholders. Really brutal.
HostA: And it’s happening across the sector. Albemarle Corporation in the U.S. saw a 10% drop since November 4th.
HostB: Even graphite companies like Talga Group are down 15%. It feels like investors are just abandoning the whole battery metals story.
HostA: Which is kind of ironic because, like, this feels like a repeat of 2019, when mining stocks boomed and then totally busted because supply way outstripped EV demand.
HostB: Exactly. And now with EV sales actually decreasing—Tesla itself had a 12% drop last year—it’s like the party’s over before it even got started again.
HostA: And Morgan Stanley just cut its lithium forecasts. They’re predicting spodumene could fall from $395 a ton to just $290.
HostB: Yeah, and lithium hydroxide might drop to $7,000 a ton by 2023. That’s a huge correction.
HostA: So even though Mercedes-Benz is leading in EVs right now, the overall demand growth is slowing. Competition is rising, but so are obstacles.
HostB: Government regulations aren’t helping either—they’re making drivers delay switching to electric.
HostA: So if surpluses pile up, these metal prices could really plummet further. Not a great outlook for miners.
HostB: Nope. Feels like we’re seeing history repeat itself, unfortunately.
